questions.question: Generally accepted auditing standards (GAAS) are organized into:

options.A: Two categories: field work and reporting
options.B: Three categories: general standards, field work standards, and reporting standards
options.C: Four categories: ethics, planning, evidence, and reporting
options.D: Five categories matching the audit process

questions.explanation: GAAS consists of three categories: (1) General Standards covering qualifications and conduct, (2) Standards of Field Work covering planning and evidence, and (3) Standards of Reporting covering the auditor's report requirements.
questions.tip: GAAS = General + Field Work + Reporting (3 categories, 10 standards).

questions.question: Audit risk is the risk that the auditor:

options.B: Issues an inappropriate opinion when the financial statements are materially misstated
options.C: Experiences a lawsuit from the client
options.D: Cannot complete the audit on time

questions.explanation: Audit risk is the risk that the auditor expresses an inappropriate audit opinion when the financial statements are materially misstated. It is a function of the risk of material misstatement (inherent risk × control risk) and detection risk.
questions.tip: Audit risk = risk of wrong opinion on materially misstated F/S.

questions.question: Materiality is used by auditors primarily to:

options.B: Plan the audit and evaluate misstatements
options.D: Choose the type of opinion to issue

questions.explanation: Materiality is used in planning the audit (to determine the nature, timing, and extent of procedures) and in evaluating whether uncorrected misstatements, individually or in aggregate, are material to the financial statements as a whole.
questions.tip: Materiality guides both planning (how much work) and evaluation (are errors significant).

questions.question: Which source of audit evidence is generally considered most reliable?

options.B: Oral representations from management
options.C: Confirmations received directly from third parties
options.D: Inquiry of client personnel

questions.explanation: External evidence obtained directly by the auditor (such as confirmations from third parties) is generally more reliable than evidence generated internally by the client. Direct receipt ensures the evidence was not altered by the client.
questions.tip: External evidence > internal evidence. Direct receipt > indirect receipt.

questions.question: The COSO internal control framework includes all of the following components EXCEPT:

options.B: Risk assessment
options.D: Monitoring activities

questions.explanation: The five COSO components are: Control Environment, Risk Assessment, Control Activities, Information and Communication, and Monitoring Activities. Audit planning is an auditor responsibility, not a component of the client's internal control.
questions.tip: COSO = CE, RA, CA, I&C, MA (Control Environment to Monitoring Activities).

questions.question: The standard unmodified audit report includes:

options.A: A guarantee of the accuracy of the financial statements
options.B: An opinion that the financial statements are presented fairly, in all material respects
options.C: A prediction of the entity's future performance
options.D: An assurance that fraud does not exist

questions.explanation: The unmodified opinion states that the financial statements present fairly, in all material respects, in accordance with the applicable financial reporting framework. The auditor provides reasonable, not absolute, assurance and does not guarantee accuracy or predict the future.
questions.tip: Unmodified opinion = 'presents fairly in all material respects.'

questions.question: Analytical procedures are required:

options.B: During planning and as a final overall review
options.D: Only when controls are ineffective

questions.explanation: Analytical procedures are required during planning (to understand the entity and identify risk areas) and near the end of the audit as an overall review (to assess whether the financial statements are consistent with the auditor's understanding). They are optional as substantive procedures.
questions.tip: Required analytics: planning + final review. Optional: substantive testing.

questions.question: A Type I subsequent event:

options.A: Occurs after year-end and requires disclosure only
options.B: Provides additional evidence about conditions existing at the balance sheet date and requires adjustment
options.D: Only applies to going concern issues

questions.explanation: Type I (recognized) subsequent events provide additional evidence about conditions that existed at the balance sheet date. These require adjustment to the financial statements. Type II events represent conditions arising after year-end and require disclosure only.
questions.tip: Type I = condition existed at year-end = adjust F/S. Type II = arose after = disclose only.

questions.question: When evaluating going concern, the auditor considers events or conditions for a period of at least:

options.A: Six months from the balance sheet date
options.B: One year from the date the financial statements are issued
options.C: One year from the balance sheet date
options.D: Two years from the balance sheet date

questions.explanation: The auditor evaluates whether there is substantial doubt about the entity's ability to continue as a going concern for a reasonable period of time—defined as one year from the date the financial statements are issued (or available to be issued).
questions.tip: Going concern period = 1 year from F/S issuance date.

questions.question: The fraud triangle consists of:

options.B: Motive, means, and method
options.D: Detection, prevention, and reporting

questions.explanation: The fraud triangle identifies three conditions typically present when fraud occurs: (1) Pressure/Incentive to commit fraud, (2) Opportunity to perpetrate fraud, and (3) Rationalization/Attitude that justifies the fraudulent behavior.
questions.tip: Fraud triangle = Pressure + Opportunity + Rationalization.

questions.question: Sampling risk is:

options.A: The risk of choosing an inappropriate sampling method
options.B: The risk that the sample is not representative of the population
options.C: The risk that the auditor makes errors in performing procedures
options.D: Always eliminated by using statistical sampling

questions.explanation: Sampling risk is the risk that the auditor's conclusion based on a sample may differ from the conclusion that would be reached if the entire population were subjected to the same procedure. It exists because only a portion of the population is tested.
questions.tip: Sampling risk = sample conclusion ≠ population conclusion. Reduced by larger samples.

questions.question: Which assertion is tested when the auditor confirms accounts receivable?

options.B: Valuation only
options.D: Presentation only

questions.explanation: Accounts receivable confirmations primarily test existence (the receivable exists), rights (the client owns the receivable), and accuracy (the amount is correct). Confirmations are less effective for completeness since unrecorded receivables won't be confirmed.
questions.tip: AR confirmations test existence and accuracy—not great for completeness.

questions.question: The management representation letter should be dated:

options.B: The date of the auditor's report
options.D: The date the financial statements are filed

questions.explanation: The management representation letter should be dated as of the date of the auditor's report. This ensures management's representations cover the entire period up to when the auditor forms an opinion, including the subsequent events period.
questions.tip: Rep letter date = auditor's report date (covers through opinion date).

questions.question: Professional skepticism requires the auditor to:

options.B: Have a questioning mind and critically assess audit evidence
options.D: Confirm every transaction with third parties

questions.explanation: Professional skepticism involves a questioning mind, being alert to conditions indicating possible misstatement due to error or fraud, and critically assessing audit evidence. It doesn't mean assuming dishonesty, but not assuming honesty either—a neutral, questioning approach.
questions.tip: Skepticism = questioning mind, not assuming honesty or dishonesty.

questions.question: The primary purpose of the engagement letter is to:

options.B: Document the terms and objectives of the engagement
options.D: Limit the auditor's liability

questions.explanation: The engagement letter establishes a mutual understanding of the engagement's terms, including objectives, scope, responsibilities of both parties, and limitations. While it may address fees and other matters, its primary purpose is documenting the engagement terms.
questions.tip: Engagement letter = mutual understanding of engagement terms and responsibilities.

questions.question: An engagement quality review is required for:

options.B: Audits of public companies and other engagements meeting criteria for EQR
options.C: Only engagements where fraud is suspected
options.D: Only first-year audit engagements

questions.explanation: Engagement quality review is required for audits of issuers (public companies) under PCAOB standards. For nonissuers, firms establish criteria for which engagements require EQR, typically including public interest entities and high-risk engagements.
questions.tip: EQR required for issuers; firm policy determines EQR for nonissuers.

questions.question: An auditor's independence is impaired if the auditor:

options.A: Provides tax compliance services to an audit client
options.B: Has a direct financial interest in the audit client, regardless of materiality
options.C: Performs compilation services for a nonissuer client
options.D: Has a family member who is an employee of the audit client

questions.explanation: A direct financial interest in an audit client impairs independence regardless of whether the interest is material. Direct interests include ownership, beneficial interest in a trust, or financial interest held through an intermediary.
questions.tip: Direct financial interest = independence impaired (no materiality exception).

questions.question: The auditor is required to communicate which of the following to those charged with governance?

options.B: Significant findings from the audit including significant audit adjustments
options.D: The auditor's assessment of management's competence

questions.explanation: Required communications include significant audit findings, including significant adjustments (whether recorded or unrecorded), significant deficiencies and material weaknesses in internal control, disagreements with management, and difficulties encountered during the audit.
questions.tip: Communicate to governance: significant findings, adjustments, IC deficiencies, disagreements.

questions.question: A significant risk is defined as a risk that:

options.A: Requires special audit consideration due to its nature or magnitude
options.B: Will always result in a material misstatement
options.D: Is detected only through analytical procedures

questions.explanation: Significant risks are identified risks of material misstatement that, in the auditor's judgment, require special audit consideration. They may arise from the nature of the risk, the magnitude of potential misstatement, or the likelihood of occurrence.
questions.tip: Significant risk = needs special attention (not all RMMs are significant risks).

questions.question: Tests of details are generally more effective than substantive analytical procedures when:

options.A: The auditor wants to reduce audit effort
options.B: Precise, item-level evidence is needed for significant risks
options.D: Internal controls are strong

questions.explanation: Tests of details provide precise evidence about specific items and are more effective when addressing significant risks or when the auditor needs to verify specific amounts. Analytical procedures are better suited for accounts with predictable, stable relationships.
questions.tip: Use tests of details for precision and significant risks; analytics for predictable relationships.

questions.question: A dual-purpose test is a test that:

options.B: Simultaneously tests internal controls and performs substantive testing on the same transactions
options.C: Is performed by two different auditors
options.D: Tests two different assertions

questions.explanation: A dual-purpose test combines a test of control and a substantive test of details performed on the same transaction or item. It is efficient when the objectives can be achieved together, but requires careful consideration of sample size requirements for each objective.
questions.tip: Dual-purpose = control test + substantive test on same items (efficient).

questions.question: When auditing related party transactions, the auditor should:

options.A: Accept management's identification of related parties without further inquiry
options.B: Perform procedures to identify related parties and evaluate transactions for proper disclosure and arm's-length terms
options.C: Only evaluate related party transactions that are unusual
options.D: Confirm all related party transactions with the related parties

questions.explanation: The auditor should perform procedures to identify related parties beyond management's representations, understand the nature of relationships and transactions, evaluate whether terms are at arm's length, and verify proper disclosure. Related party transactions pose higher fraud risk.
questions.tip: Related parties = identify independently + evaluate terms + verify disclosure.

questions.question: When using the work of an auditor's specialist, the auditor should:

options.A: Accept the specialist's findings without further evaluation
options.B: Evaluate the competence and objectivity of the specialist and the appropriateness of the specialist's work
options.C: Reference the specialist in the audit report
options.D: Engage only specialists employed by the audit firm

questions.explanation: The auditor must evaluate the specialist's competence, capabilities, and objectivity, understand the specialist's field, and evaluate whether the specialist's work is adequate for audit purposes. The specialist is not mentioned in an unmodified report as the auditor retains sole responsibility.
questions.tip: Using specialist = evaluate competence/objectivity + assess adequacy of work.

questions.question: An emphasis-of-matter paragraph is added to the audit report when:

options.A: The auditor wants to qualify the opinion
options.B: A matter is appropriately presented but is fundamental to users' understanding of the financial statements
options.C: There is a material misstatement in the financial statements
options.D: The auditor disagrees with an accounting policy

questions.explanation: An emphasis-of-matter paragraph draws attention to a matter that is appropriately presented or disclosed in the financial statements but is of such importance that it is fundamental to users' understanding. It does not modify the opinion. Examples include significant uncertainties or related party transactions.
questions.tip: Emphasis paragraph = appropriately disclosed but fundamental to understanding (opinion not modified).

questions.question: When the prior period was audited by a predecessor auditor whose report is not reissued, the successor auditor should:

options.B: Include an other-matter paragraph identifying the predecessor and the type of opinion issued
options.C: Issue a disclaimer on the prior period
options.D: Not refer to the prior period in any way

questions.explanation: When comparative financial statements are presented and the predecessor's report is not reissued, the successor auditor should include an other-matter paragraph stating that the prior period was audited by another auditor, the date and type of opinion, and any modifications.
questions.tip: Predecessor not reissuing = successor adds other-matter paragraph about prior audit.

questions.question: When evaluating uncorrected misstatements, the auditor should consider:

options.A: Only the quantitative amount of each misstatement
options.B: The effect of misstatements individually and in aggregate, including qualitative factors
options.D: Only misstatements identified through testing, not analytical procedures

questions.explanation: The auditor evaluates uncorrected misstatements both individually and in aggregate. Qualitative factors matter—a small misstatement may be material if it changes a trend, affects compliance with covenants, or involves fraud. All identified misstatements must be considered.
questions.tip: Evaluate misstatements: quantitative (amount) + qualitative (nature, effect) + aggregate.

questions.question: A significant difference between PCAOB and AICPA auditor's reports is that PCAOB reports:

options.B: Include critical audit matters (CAMs) for large accelerated filers
options.C: Do not require the auditor's signature
options.D: Are addressed to management rather than shareholders

questions.explanation: PCAOB reports for large accelerated filers must include Critical Audit Matters (CAMs)—matters communicated to the audit committee that relate to significant accounts and involve especially challenging, subjective, or complex auditor judgment.
questions.tip: PCAOB = CAMs required for large accelerated filers + integrated audit of ICFR.

questions.question: A SOC 1 Type 2 report differs from a Type 1 report in that the Type 2 report:

options.A: Covers a point in time rather than a period
options.B: Includes tests of operating effectiveness of controls over a period
options.D: Does not address internal control

questions.explanation: A SOC 1 Type 1 report addresses the design of controls at a point in time. A Type 2 report includes both the description and design of controls AND tests of operating effectiveness over a specified period, providing more assurance about whether controls operated effectively.
questions.tip: Type 1 = design at a point. Type 2 = design + operating effectiveness over time.

questions.question: In order of highest to lowest assurance, the services are:

options.B: Review, audit, compilation, preparation
options.D: Audit, compilation, review, preparation

questions.explanation: The hierarchy from highest to lowest assurance is: Audit (reasonable assurance), Review (limited assurance), Compilation (no assurance), and Preparation (no assurance and no report required). Each service level has different procedures and reporting requirements.
questions.tip: Assurance hierarchy: Audit > Review > Compilation > Preparation.

questions.question: Government Auditing Standards (Yellow Book) differ from GAAS primarily in their:

options.B: Additional requirements for independence, CPE, peer review, and reporting on internal control and compliance
options.D: Different opinion types

questions.explanation: Yellow Book incorporates GAAS but adds requirements for: (1) more stringent independence rules, (2) specific CPE requirements including government-focused training, (3) peer review, and (4) additional reporting on internal control and compliance with laws and regulations.
questions.tip: Yellow Book = GAAS + stricter independence, CPE, peer review, and compliance reporting.

questions.question: When performing substantive procedures at an interim date, the auditor should:

options.A: Not perform any procedures at year-end
options.B: Perform additional procedures to cover the remaining period from interim to year-end
options.C: Only test high-risk areas at interim
options.D: Rely solely on analytical procedures for the remaining period

questions.explanation: When substantive procedures are performed at interim, the auditor must obtain audit evidence about the remaining period. This may involve additional substantive procedures, tests of controls operating in the remaining period, or substantive analytical procedures.
questions.tip: Interim testing requires additional procedures to cover remaining period to year-end.

questions.question: Before accepting an engagement, a successor auditor should:

options.B: Make inquiries of the predecessor auditor after obtaining client permission
options.C: Contact the SEC about the client
options.D: Review the prior year's tax returns

questions.explanation: The successor auditor should request client permission to contact the predecessor, then inquire about matters that might affect the decision to accept the engagement (integrity of management, disagreements, reasons for the change). The predecessor is required to respond.
questions.tip: Successor must get client permission, then inquire of predecessor before accepting.

questions.question: Under common law, an auditor may be liable to a third party who is not in privity of contract if the auditor:

options.B: Was grossly negligent or committed fraud, depending on jurisdiction
options.D: Failed to detect all fraud

questions.explanation: Auditor liability to third parties varies by jurisdiction. Some jurisdictions require privity (Ultramares doctrine), others extend liability to known or foreseen third parties (Restatement approach), and others allow suits by any foreseeable user. Gross negligence or fraud typically overcomes privity limitations.
questions.tip: Third-party liability varies by jurisdiction—gross negligence/fraud broadens liability.

questions.question: When financial statements are prepared using a special purpose framework (such as cash basis), the auditor's report should:

options.B: Include an emphasis-of-matter paragraph describing the framework and its basis
options.D: Be identical to a report on GAAP financial statements

questions.explanation: Reports on special purpose frameworks include an emphasis-of-matter paragraph that describes the special purpose framework, refers to the note explaining the basis, and indicates the financial statements may not be suitable for other purposes. An alert paragraph may also be included.
questions.tip: Special purpose framework report = emphasis paragraph describing the framework.

questions.question: When reading other information included in documents containing audited financial statements, if the auditor identifies a material inconsistency:

options.A: The auditor must withdraw from the engagement
options.B: The auditor should determine whether the financial statements or other information needs revision
options.C: The auditor should ignore it since it's not part of the audited statements
options.D: The auditor must issue an adverse opinion

questions.explanation: When a material inconsistency exists between the audited financial statements and other information, the auditor must determine which information is correct. If the financial statements require revision and management refuses, the opinion may need to be modified. If the other information is incorrect, the auditor should request correction or consider implications for the report.
questions.tip: Material inconsistency = determine what's wrong (F/S or other info) and take appropriate action.
